aspace_helpers.title: test new ASpace plugin for component-level aspace2alma

comments.body:
This is now working from aspace staging to sftp staging. Next steps:

- [ ] test current export file in Alma Sandbox. This needs to be done manually since the Sandbox doesn't allow scheduled jobs.
- [x] disable plugin in staging
- [x] upgrade user_defined_in_basic in prod
- [x] update config of user_defined_in_basic in prod
- [x] update config yml in prod
- [x] enable plugin in prod
- [x] add aspace prod to sftp allow list
- [ ] switch plugin in prod from sftp staging to sftp prod--this will be done on or after the sftp migration Wed 5/24

Plugin on prod results in "page missing" where the ao export report page should be. That's unexpected. All the issues we had on staging before resulted in a report page that reported "sftp_fail", so this is different.

Blake is seeing a timeout error that suggests it did run but couldn't upload to the server. I'll check tomorrow to see whether the behavior has changed with the new firewall rule in place.

orangelight.title: Investigate increasing solr app server resources

comments.body:
# How much of the index can reside in memory?

```
du -h /solr/data/ | grep catalog # our collection takes up 79 gigs of disk
All solr collections together are 175 GB.
free -h # the boxes only have 38 gigs of RAM
```

So, if solr only put the catalog in memory and left all other indexes on disk, it could still only fit half of the catalog into memory.  It is likely putting parts of the other cores into memory too, so probably only a small portion of the catalog collection is in memory


# Do these boxes go to disk frequently?

This information can be found in our [Solr Health Dashboard](https://app.datadoghq.com/dashboard/ce3-krc-gid/solr-health-dashboard)

In general, the catalog collections have a high (good) filter cache hit ratio and query result cache hit ratio.  The document cache hit ratio is much lower (about 12%).  The document cache evictions seems very high to me (97,234,000 in one week).  According to the [solr documentation](https://solr.apache.org/guide/solr/latest/configuration-guide/caches-warming.html#document-cache), "The size for the documentCache should always be greater than max_results times the max_concurrent_queries, to ensure that Solr does not need to refetch a document during a request."  We have the size set to 4096, but according to my understanding, this should actually be:

100 (maximum results/page available in the UI) x 300 (maximum concurrent requests available in passenger across the 3 app servers) + 1 (because it is supposed to be greater) = 30_001

This disregards the fact that users can enter a custom per_page in the search results URL, and also that sitemaps request more than 100 rows at a time.

# How is CPU usage?

I looked at the [Datadog metrics explorer](https://app.datadoghq.com/metric/explorer), and it seems very reasonable on production.  It seems over-resourced on staging.

# How is disk usage?

Plenty of space

# What storage medium is used?

```
pulsys@lib-solr-prod4:~$ lsblk -o name,rota
NAME               ROTA
sda                   1
└─sda1                1
  ├─lib--vg-root      1
  └─lib--vg-swap_1    1
sdb                   1
└─sdb1                1
  └─lib--vg-root      1
sdc                   1
└─sdc1                1
  └─lib--vg-root      1
sr0                   1
```
A rota of 1 indicates that it is a rotational device, and hence, not an SSD.

# Recommendations

1. Substantially increase the amount of RAM available to the catalog collection
1. Increase the document cache size

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/60413389/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/60413389)

Coverage: 95.384%. Remained the same when pulling **a82265f8b36a79305f4049fa1a319dd9cb866bbc on 3572-rate-limit-sitemap** into **22c41d07eb90c69d3c7f2b41c3bab90605de283a on main**.

orangelight.title: Multi-Item Special Collections Holding Fails to Load Request Form

comments.body:
@kevinreiss and I looked at this today.  We found:

- This example record has more than 500 items, so the `too_many_items?` method returns true
- The `too_many_items?` behavior is set up to show the fill_in form for non-SC items, but it throws an error for aeon items.
- We're not sure yet what the desired behavior is.  The ideas we discussed were:
    - Ignoring `too_many_items?` for special collection materials
    - Showing the fill_in form for SC materials.  This is not a good option, because the circulation department handles the fill_in form, not special collections.
    - Linking directly to aeon in this case.  We are currently pre-populating the form with the first item from the holdings_1display, which is not great, since it is probably not be the item that somebody wants.  We could leave it blank (but the show page doesn't show which items are available).

This issue affects 30 records in the catalog.
